column13: The biggest barrier to educational equity is definitely the differences in education in classes prior to high school. Due to a lack of unified curriculum, you can have students coming into high school ranging from having taken algebra, to some having taken calculus. At the same time, differences in foreign language ability and English comprehension can also act as a barrier. If all students could learn the same stuff (eg, not spend 4 years on algebra for some reason in middle school and actually learn math, or be expected to have a certain level of English comprehension in school), it could allow everyone to start off on relatively the same foot and increase equity in schools.

I would say the biggest barrier to educational equity at CPSD would probably be family resources. I want to share a personal story about this matter. My best friend, whom is also a 9th grader, has parents who did not go to college. The school we used to go to was not very good and I feel like they did not give out good resources for the students to work with. I was home schooled for 2 years between 5th to 6th grade, so, I was not there with my friend. When I came back in 7th grade my friend was failing almost all of her classes because she was hanging around the wrong crowd and because, even if her parents wanted to help her out, they couldn't because they didn't know any better. Since she is my best friend, my parents offered to take her with us to the library to finish homework every Wednesday. (My parents both graduated college and my dad has a PhD). My parents were able to teach her the things my school failed to. I forgot to mention the fact that my school was so bad that I had to re-learn the multiplication tables in 5th grade with my mom in home school because at my school they had not taught them properly at all. Anywho, my friend is now good with her grades! (she has mostly B's and some A's!). I feel that more elementary schools should have the opportunity to have tutors or to attempt encouraging the students to find a tutor that the district provides. In my school there was only one teacher that all of the students had really good grades with because she actually taught us properly and we understood. She was our science teacher between the years of 7th grade and 8th grade.
Anyways this is all I have to share.
P.S. My school's name is "Amigos" and the amazing science teacher is Ms. Ferhani or Laurie Ferhani.
